==Early life==
==Early life==
He was born Edmund John Chisholm Dwyer Gray on 2 April 1870 in [[Dublin]], Ireland, the son of [[Edmund Dwyer Gray (Irish politician)|Edmund Dwyer Gray]], an MP in the [[British House of Commons]] and [[Caroline Agnes Gray]]. He was the maternal grandson of [[Caroline Chisholm]], the English humanitarian renowned for her social welfare work with female immigrants to Australia. His paternal grandfather was [[John Gray (Irish politician)|Sir John Gray]], the Irish Member of Parliament for [[Kilkenny City (UK Parliament constituency)|Kilkenny City]] in the House of Commons, and an associate of the Irish nationalist [[Daniel O'Connell]]. He was educated at the [[Benedictine]] monastery at [[Fort Augustus]], [[Scotland]], and at [[Clongowes Wood College]], a [[Jesuit]] school in [[County Kildare]].<ref name="adb">R. P. Davis, [https://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/dwyergray-edmund-john-6068 'Dwyer-Gray, Edmund John Chisholm (1870–1945)'] , ''[[Australian Dictionary of Biography]]'', Volume 8, [[Melbourne University Press]], 1981, pp 390–391.</ref>
He was born Edmund John Chisholm Dwyer Gray on 2 April 1870 in [[Dublin]], Ireland, the son of [[Edmund Dwyer Gray (Irish politician)|Edmund Dwyer Gray]], an MP in the [[British House of Commons]] and [[Caroline Agnes Gray]]. He was the maternal grandson of [[Caroline Chisholm]], the English humanitarian renowned for her social welfare work with female immigrants to Australia. His paternal grandfather was [[John Gray (Irish politician)|Sir John Gray]], the Irish Member of Parliament for [[Kilkenny City (UK Parliament constituency)|Kilkenny City]] in the House of Commons, and an associate of the Irish nationalist [[Daniel O'Connell]]. He was educated at the [[Benedictine]] monastery at [[Fort Augustus]], [[Scotland]], and at [[Clongowes Wood College]], a [[Jesuit]] school in [[County Kildare]].<ref name="adb">R. P. Davis, [https://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/dwyergray-edmund-john-6068 'Dwyer-Gray, Edmund John Chisholm (1870–1945)'], ''[[Australian Dictionary of Biography]]'', Volume 8, [[Melbourne University Press]], 1981, pp 390–391.</ref>

source_payload.html:
History

← Previous revision Revision as of 22:58, 7 February 2026
Line 12: Line 12:


==History==
==History==
The people referred to in Greek texts as Blemmyes may have their earliest mention as Egyptian ''Bwrꜣhꜣyw'' in the Kushite enthronement stela of [[Anlamani]] from [[Kawa (Sudan)|Kawa]] from the late seventh century BC. The representation ''Brhrm'' in a petition from [[El Hiba]] one century later may reflect the same root term. Similar terms recur in Egyptian sources from later centuries with more certain correspondence to the Greek etymon of ''Blemmyes''.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Barnard|first1=Hans|editor1-last=Starkey|editor1-first=Janet|title=People of the Red Sea: Proceedings of Red Sea Project II Held in the British Museum October 2004|year=2005|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford|isbn=1-84171-833-5|pages=23–40|chapter=Sire, il n'y a pas de Blemmyes: A Re-Evaluation of Historical and Archaeological Data}}</ref> In Coptic, Ⲃⲁⲗⲛⲉⲙⲙⲱⲟⲩⲓ, ''Balnemmōui'', is widely accepted as equivalent to Greek Βλέμμυης, ''Blémmuēs''.<ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Eide |editor1-first=Tormod|editor2-last=Hägg|editor2-first=Tomas|editor3-last=Pierce|editor3-first=Richard Holton|editor4-last=Török|editor4-first=László |title=Fontes Historiae Nubiorum, Vol. III: From the First to the Sixth Century AD|year=1998|publisher=Institutt for klassisk filologi, russisk og religionsvitenskap, Seksjon for gresk, latin og egyptologi, Universitetet i Bergen|location=Bergen|isbn=82-91626-07-3|page=1108}}</ref>
The people referred to in Greek texts as Blemmyes may have their earliest mention as Egyptian ''Bwrꜣhꜣyw'' in the Kushite enthronement stela of [[Anlamani]] from [[Kawa (Sudan)|Kawa]] from the late seventh century BC. The representation ''Brhrm'' in a petition from [[El Hiba]] one century later may reflect the same root term. Similar terms recur in Egyptian sources from later centuries with more certain correspondence to the Greek etymon of ''Blemmyes''.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Barnard|first1=Hans|editor1-last=Starkey|editor1-first=Janet|title=People of the Red Sea: Proceedings of Red Sea Project II Held in the British Museum October 2004|year=2005|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford|isbn=1-84171-833-5|pages=23–40|chapter=Sire, il n'y a pas de Blemmyes: A Re-Evaluation of Historical and Archaeological Data}}</ref> In Coptic, Ⲃⲁⲗⲛⲉⲙⲙⲱⲟⲩⲓ, ''Balnemmōui'', is widely accepted as equivalent to Greek Βλέμμυες, ''Blémmues''.<ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Eide |editor1-first=Tormod|editor2-last=Hägg|editor2-first=Tomas|editor3-last=Pierce|editor3-first=Richard Holton|editor4-last=Török|editor4-first=László |title=Fontes Historiae Nubiorum, Vol. III: From the First to the Sixth Century AD|year=1998|publisher=Institutt for klassisk filologi, russisk og religionsvitenskap, Seksjon for gresk, latin og egyptologi, Universitetet i Bergen|location=Bergen|isbn=82-91626-07-3|page=1108}}</ref>


The Greek term first appears in the third century BC in one of the poems of [[Theocritus]] and in [[Eratosthenes]], who is cited in [[Strabo]]'s ''[[Geographica]]'' (first century AD).<ref name="Dijkstra2013"/><ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Eide|editor1-first=Tormod|editor2-last=Hägg|editor2-first=Tomas|editor3-last=Pierce|editor3-first=Richard Holton|editor4-last=Török|editor4-first=László|title=Fontes Historia Nubiorum, Vol. II: From the Mid-Fifth to the First Century BC|year=1996|publisher=Institutt for klassik filologi, russisk og religionsvitenskap, Seksjon for gresk, latin og egyptologi, Universitetet i Bergen|location=Bergen|isbn=82-91626-01-4|pages=560, 569}}</ref> Eratosthenes described the Blemmyes as living with the Megabaroi in the land between the Nile and the Red Sea north of [[Meroë]]. Strabo himself, locating them south of [[Syene]] (Aswan), describes them as [[nomad]]ic raiders but not bellicose. In later writings, the Blemmyes are described in stereotypical terms as barbarians living south of Egypt. [[Pomponius Mela]] and [[Pliny the Elder]] described them as [[Headless men|headless beings with their faces on their chests]].<ref name="Dijkstra2013"/>
The Greek term first appears in the third century BC in one of the poems of [[Theocritus]] and in [[Eratosthenes]], who is cited in [[Strabo]]'s ''[[Geographica]]'' (first century AD).<ref name="Dijkstra2013"/><ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Eide|editor1-first=Tormod|editor2-last=Hägg|editor2-first=Tomas|editor3-last=Pierce|editor3-first=Richard Holton|editor4-last=Török|editor4-first=László|title=Fontes Historia Nubiorum, Vol. II: From the Mid-Fifth to the First Century BC|year=1996|publisher=Institutt for klassik filologi, russisk og religionsvitenskap, Seksjon for gresk, latin og egyptologi, Universitetet i Bergen|location=Bergen|isbn=82-91626-01-4|pages=560, 569}}</ref> Eratosthenes described the Blemmyes as living with the Megabaroi in the land between the Nile and the Red Sea north of [[Meroë]]. Strabo himself, locating them south of [[Syene]] (Aswan), describes them as [[nomad]]ic raiders but not bellicose. In later writings, the Blemmyes are described in stereotypical terms as barbarians living south of Egypt. [[Pomponius Mela]] and [[Pliny the Elder]] described them as [[Headless men|headless beings with their faces on their chests]].<ref name="Dijkstra2013"/>

Carlson played his youth cricket at [[Cardiff Cricket Club]]. He made his first class debut on 31 August 2016 despite being 5'5, against [[Northamptonshire County Cricket Club|Northamptonshire]], having been brought to the team as an injury replacement for [[Craig Meschede]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Cardiff teenager Kiran Carlson takes five-wicket haul on Glamorgan first-class dream debut with his part-time spin|url=https://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/cricket/cardiff-teenager-kiran-carlson-takes-11826560|publisher=[[WalesOnline]]|date=31 August 2016}}</ref> He made his [[Twenty20]] debut for Glamorgan in the [[2017 NatWest t20 Blast]] on 7 July 2017.<ref name="T20">{{Cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/1068301.html |title=NatWest t20 Blast, South Group: Glamorgan v Hampshire at Cardiff, Jul 7, 2017 |access-date=7 July 2017 |work=ESPN Cricinfo}}</ref>
Carlson played his youth cricket at [[Cardiff Cricket Club]]. He made his first class debut on 31 August 2016 against [[Northamptonshire County Cricket Club|Northamptonshire]], having been brought to the team as an injury replacement for [[Craig Meschede]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Cardiff teenager Kiran Carlson takes five-wicket haul on Glamorgan first-class dream debut with his part-time spin|url=https://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/cricket/cardiff-teenager-kiran-carlson-takes-11826560|publisher=[[WalesOnline]]|date=31 August 2016}}</ref> He made his [[Twenty20]] debut for Glamorgan in the [[2017 NatWest t20 Blast]] on 7 July 2017.<ref name="T20">{{Cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/1068301.html |title=NatWest t20 Blast, South Group: Glamorgan v Hampshire at Cardiff, Jul 7, 2017 |access-date=7 July 2017 |work=ESPN Cricinfo}}</ref>


In 2021 Carlson captained Glamorgan to victory in the final of the [[Royal London One-Day Cup]], top-scoring in Glamorgan's innings with 82.<ref name=RLC/>

It's 2025, and no Dirty Dancing sequel came out then. Maybe this year, or next...

← Previous revision Revision as of 22:58, 7 February 2026
Line 40: Line 40:
''Dirty Dancing'' premiered at the [[Cannes Film Festival]] on May 12, 1987 and was released on August 21 in the United States, earning over $214 million worldwide—$64 million in the US and Canada and $150 million in other territories.<ref>{{cite web |title=Dirty Dancing |url=https://www.boxofficemojo.com/title/tt0092890/ |website=[[Box Office Mojo]]}}</ref> It earned positive reviews from critics, who particularly praised the performances of Grey and Swayze, and its [[Dirty Dancing (soundtrack)|soundtrack]], created by [[Jimmy Ienner]], generated two multi-[[Music recording sales certification|platinum]] albums, and multiple singles. "[[(I've Had) The Time of My Life]]", performed by [[Bill Medley]] and [[Jennifer Warnes]], won the [[Academy Award for Best Original Song]], the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Original Song]], and the [[Grammy Award for Best Pop Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Craughwell |first=Kathleen |date=August 18, 1997 |title=Save the Last Dirty Dance for the Revival |url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1997-aug-18-ca-23531-story.html |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |access-date=July 2, 2021}}</ref> In 2024, the film was selected for preservation in the United States [[National Film Registry]] by the [[Library of Congress]] as being "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant".<ref name="2024NFR">{{cite web|title=25 Films Added to National Film Registry for Preservation|url= https://newsroom.loc.gov/news/25-films-named-to-national-film-registry-for-preservation/s/55d5285d-916f-4105-b7d4-7fc3ba8664e3|date=December 17, 2024|access-date=December 17, 2024}}</ref>
''Dirty Dancing'' premiered at the [[Cannes Film Festival]] on May 12, 1987 and was released on August 21 in the United States, earning over $214 million worldwide—$64 million in the US and Canada and $150 million in other territories.<ref>{{cite web |title=Dirty Dancing |url=https://www.boxofficemojo.com/title/tt0092890/ |website=[[Box Office Mojo]]}}</ref> It earned positive reviews from critics, who particularly praised the performances of Grey and Swayze, and its [[Dirty Dancing (soundtrack)|soundtrack]], created by [[Jimmy Ienner]], generated two multi-[[Music recording sales certification|platinum]] albums, and multiple singles. "[[(I've Had) The Time of My Life]]", performed by [[Bill Medley]] and [[Jennifer Warnes]], won the [[Academy Award for Best Original Song]], the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Original Song]], and the [[Grammy Award for Best Pop Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Craughwell |first=Kathleen |date=August 18, 1997 |title=Save the Last Dirty Dance for the Revival |url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1997-aug-18-ca-23531-story.html |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |access-date=July 2, 2021}}</ref> In 2024, the film was selected for preservation in the United States [[National Film Registry]] by the [[Library of Congress]] as being "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant".<ref name="2024NFR">{{cite web|title=25 Films Added to National Film Registry for Preservation|url= https://newsroom.loc.gov/news/25-films-named-to-national-film-registry-for-preservation/s/55d5285d-916f-4105-b7d4-7fc3ba8664e3|date=December 17, 2024|access-date=December 17, 2024}}</ref>


The film's popularity successfully launched its [[Dirty Dancing (franchise)|titular franchise]], including a [[Dirty Dancing (1988 TV series)|1988 television series]], multiple [[Reality television|reality competition shows]], a 2004 [[prequel]] titled ''[[Dirty Dancing: Havana Nights]]'', a stage production which has had sellout performances in multiple countries, a [[television film|made-for-television]] [[Musical film|musical]] [[Dirty Dancing (2017 film)|adaptation]] in 2017, and an [[Dirty Dancing (franchise)#Untitled sequel (2025)|untitled sequel]] scheduled to be released in 2025 with Grey reprising her role.<ref name="premiere">{{cite web |last=Robbins |first=Caryn |date=January 10, 2017 |title=ABC Announces May Premiere Date for Dirty Dancing Event Movie |url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/ABC-Announces-May-Premiere-Date-for-DIRTY-DANCING-Event-Movie-20170110 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170223153315/http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/ABC-Announces-May-Premiere-Date-for-DIRTY-DANCING-Event-Movie-20170110 |archive-date=February 23, 2017 |url-status=live |website=[[BroadwayWorld]] |access-date=March 11, 2017}}</ref>
The film's popularity successfully launched its [[Dirty Dancing (franchise)|titular franchise]], including a [[Dirty Dancing (1988 TV series)|1988 television series]], multiple [[Reality television|reality competition shows]], a 2004 [[prequel]] titled ''[[Dirty Dancing: Havana Nights]]'', a stage production which has had sellout performances in multiple countries, a [[television film|made-for-television]] [[Musical film|musical]] [[Dirty Dancing (2017 film)|adaptation]] in 2017, and an [[Dirty Dancing (franchise)#Untitled sequel (2025)|untitled sequel]] with Grey reprising her role.<ref name="premiere">{{cite web |last=Robbins |first=Caryn |date=January 10, 2017 |title=ABC Announces May Premiere Date for Dirty Dancing Event Movie |url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/ABC-Announces-May-Premiere-Date-for-DIRTY-DANCING-Event-Movie-20170110 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170223153315/http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/ABC-Announces-May-Premiere-Date-for-DIRTY-DANCING-Event-Movie-20170110 |archive-date=February 23, 2017 |url-status=live |website=[[BroadwayWorld]] |access-date=March 11, 2017}}</ref>

source_payload.html:
HTTP to HTTPS for Wayback Machine, replaced: http://web.archive.org/ → https://web.archive.org/ (2)

← Previous revision Revision as of 22:58, 7 February 2026
Line 43: Line 43:
=== Alleged cover-up of the 2010 death of Anastasio Hernández Rojas ===
=== Alleged cover-up of the 2010 death of Anastasio Hernández Rojas ===
{{See also|Death of Anastasio Hernández-Rojas}}
{{See also|Death of Anastasio Hernández-Rojas}}
Former CBP deputy assistant commissioner James Wong testified that, while Scott was San Diego Sector chief, he “supervised” a Critical Incident Team’s handling of [[Anastasio Hernández Rojas]]’s beating and tasing by Border Patrol agents. Scott allegedly used an administrative subpoena to obtain medical records during an active criminal probe, delayed notifications to local authorities, mishandled evidence, and allowed key video footage to be erased. Although the Justice Department declined to press charges, a wrongful-death suit was settled for $1 million in 2017. Senator [[Ron Wyden]] has since subpoenaed DHS records to examine Scott’s role.<ref>{{Cite news |date=2025-04-23 |title=Senator probes CBP nominee's alleged interference in migrant death investigation |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/immigration/2025/04/23/cbp-trump-rodney-scott-migrant-death/ |archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20250508013055/https://www.washingtonpost.com/immigration/2025/04/23/cbp-trump-rodney-scott-migrant-death/ |archive-date=2025-05-08 |access-date=2025-06-27 |newspaper=The Washington Post |language=en}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite news |last=Stein |first=Chris |date=2025-06-18 |title=Rodney Scott confirmed as head of CBP by US Senate despite 'cover-up' claim |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/jun/18/rodney-scott-cbp-confirmation |access-date=2025-06-27 |work=The Guardian |language=en-GB |issn=0261-3077}}</ref>
Former CBP deputy assistant commissioner James Wong testified that, while Scott was San Diego Sector chief, he “supervised” a Critical Incident Team’s handling of [[Anastasio Hernández Rojas]]’s beating and tasing by Border Patrol agents. Scott allegedly used an administrative subpoena to obtain medical records during an active criminal probe, delayed notifications to local authorities, mishandled evidence, and allowed key video footage to be erased. Although the Justice Department declined to press charges, a wrongful-death suit was settled for $1 million in 2017. Senator [[Ron Wyden]] has since subpoenaed DHS records to examine Scott’s role.<ref>{{Cite news |date=2025-04-23 |title=Senator probes CBP nominee's alleged interference in migrant death investigation |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/immigration/2025/04/23/cbp-trump-rodney-scott-migrant-death/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20250508013055/https://www.washingtonpost.com/immigration/2025/04/23/cbp-trump-rodney-scott-migrant-death/ |archive-date=2025-05-08 |access-date=2025-06-27 |newspaper=The Washington Post |language=en}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite news |last=Stein |first=Chris |date=2025-06-18 |title=Rodney Scott confirmed as head of CBP by US Senate despite 'cover-up' claim |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/jun/18/rodney-scott-cbp-confirmation |access-date=2025-06-27 |work=The Guardian |language=en-GB |issn=0261-3077}}</ref>


In April 2025, a San Diego law firm formally petitioned the U.S. attorney general, FBI director, and DHS inspector general to probe Scott for potential violations of the [[Ethics in Government Act]] (18 U.S.C. § 207) relating to his post–Border Patrol employment activities and use of official subpoena power during the 2010 Hernández Rojas case.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2025-04-28 |title=Former Border Patrol chief faces scrutiny ahead of confirmation hearing to lead CBP |url=https://www.cbs8.com/article/news/local/former-border-patrol-chief-under-scrutiny-ahead-of-confirmation-hearing-lead-cbp/509-c8f3b279-6219-4fd2-8829-012f8694e85f |access-date=2025-06-27 |website=cbs8.com |language=en-US}}</ref>

==== Rape threat tweet ====
In September 2021, Scott sent a tweet to former senior Border Patrol agent and whistleblower in Hernández Rojas case Jenn Budd that a [[San Diego County Superior Court|San Diego Superior Court]] judge described as a “classic" rape threat. During his April 2025 confirmation hearing, Scott apologized, calling it a “weak moment” and insisting he meant to challenge her “creative imagination” about her allegations—an explanation that stunned senators and watchdogs.<ref>{{Cite news |date=2025-04-30 |title=Trump's CBP nominee questioned on immigrant's death at confirmation hearing |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/immigration/2025/04/30/trump-cbp-rodney-scott-confirmation/ |archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20250501181010/https://www.washingtonpost.com/immigration/2025/04/30/trump-cbp-rodney-scott-confirmation/ |archive-date=2025-05-01 |access-date=2025-06-27 |newspaper=The Washington Post |language=en}}</ref>

Gukesh learned to play chess at the age of seven, and eventually began structured one-hour sessions three times a week.<ref>{{cite web |last=Lokpria Vasudevan |date=17 January 2019 |title=D Gukesh: Grit and determination personify India's youngest Grandmaster |url=https://www.indiatoday.in/sports/other-sports/story/d-gukesh-grit-and-determination-personify-india-s-youngest-grandmaster-1433361-2019-01-17 |access-date=18 March 2019 |work=[[India Today]] |archive-date=27 March 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190327091501/https://www.indiatoday.in/sports/other-sports/story/d-gukesh-grit-and-determination-personify-india-s-youngest-grandmaster-1433361-2019-01-17 |url-status=live }}</ref> He dropped out of school after Class IV (in [[primary school|elementary school]]) to focus on his chess career. In 2017, his father quit his job to travel with Gukesh to various tournaments; Gukesh was sponsored by his parents' friends at this time,<ref>{{cite web |date=13 December 2024 |title=Gukesh stopped regular school at class IV, no sponsor, father quit job, mother had to…: Story of youngest world champ |url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/sports/others/gukesh-stopped-school-at-class-iv-no-sponsor-father-quit-job-mother-sole-bread-earner-story-of-youngest-world-champ-101734063688084.html |work=[[The Hindustan Times]]}}</ref> support about which he has often spoken since.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://m.thewire.in/article/sport/gukesh-dommaraju/amp|title=Gukesh Dommaraju, The Boy Who Foretold His Future|website=thewire.in}}</ref> His extraordinary talent was recognized institutionally early on, and he became one of the many beneficiaries of the robust Indian chess ecosystem.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c23vn7x4012o|title=Gukesh Dommaraju: How the Indian teenager became youngest world chess champion|work=[[BBC News]]|date=13 December 2024|access-date=13 December 2024|archive-date=13 December 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20241213043941/https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c23vn7x4012o|url-status=live}}</ref> Gukesh studied at Velammal Vidyalaya Ayanambakkam, along with top player [[R Praggnanandhaa]].{{Cn|date=January 2026}}
Gukesh learned to play chess at the age of seven, and eventually began structured one-hour sessions three times a week.<ref>{{cite web |last=Lokpria Vasudevan |date=17 January 2019 |title=D Gukesh: Grit and determination personify India's youngest Grandmaster |url=https://www.indiatoday.in/sports/other-sports/story/d-gukesh-grit-and-determination-personify-india-s-youngest-grandmaster-1433361-2019-01-17 |access-date=18 March 2019 |work=[[India Today]] |archive-date=27 March 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190327091501/https://www.indiatoday.in/sports/other-sports/story/d-gukesh-grit-and-determination-personify-india-s-youngest-grandmaster-1433361-2019-01-17 |url-status=live }}</ref> He dropped out of school after Class IV (in [[primary school|elementary school]]) to focus on his chess career. In 2017, his father quit his job to travel with Gukesh to various tournaments; Gukesh was sponsored by his parents' friends at this time,<ref>{{cite web |date=13 December 2024 |title=Gukesh stopped regular school at class IV, no sponsor, father quit job, mother had to…: Story of youngest world champ |url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/sports/others/gukesh-stopped-school-at-class-iv-no-sponsor-father-quit-job-mother-sole-bread-earner-story-of-youngest-world-champ-101734063688084.html |work=[[The Hindustan Times]]}}</ref> support about which he has often spoken since.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://m.thewire.in/article/sport/gukesh-dommaraju/amp|title=Gukesh Dommaraju, The Boy Who Foretold His Future|website=thewire.in}}</ref> His extraordinary talent was recognized institutionally early on, and he became one of the many beneficiaries of the robust Indian chess ecosystem.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c23vn7x4012o|title=Gukesh Dommaraju: How the Indian teenager became youngest world chess champion|work=[[BBC News]]|date=13 December 2024|access-date=13 December 2024|archive-date=13 December 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20241213043941/https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c23vn7x4012o|url-status=live}}</ref> Gukesh studied at Velammal Vidyalaya Ayanambakkam, along with top player [[R Praggnanandhaa]].{{Cn|date=January 2026}}


Gukesh's childhood coach, GM [[Vishnu Prasanna V.|Vishnu Prasanna]], restrained him from using [[Chess engine|chess engines]] for analysis and training during the formative years of his career, in what has been described as a "radical experiment", with goal of developing independent analytical skills and intuition; he started using engines after crossing the 2500 rating threshold.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-11-20 |title=How Gukesh was shaped by a radical ‘experiment’ proposed at age of 11 by his coach Vishnu Prasanna |url=https://indianexpress.com/article/sports/chess/how-gukesh-was-shaped-by-radical-experiment-age-11-vishnu-prasanna-9677457/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.ph/ozkAo |archive-date=2025-10-15 |access-date=2026-01-29 |website=The Indian Express |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-10-25 |title=Gukesh wins Candidates: The boy raised without chess engines who’ll challenge Ding Liren at World Championships |url=https://indianexpress.com/article/sports/chess/gukesh-wins-candidates-17-year-old-raised-without-chess-engines-ding-liren-world-chess-championships-9283580/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240422014020/http://indianexpress.com/article/sports/chess/gukesh-wins-candidates-17-year-old-raised-without-chess-engines-ding-liren-world-chess-championships-9283580/ |archive-date=2024-04-22 |access-date=2026-01-29 |website=The Indian Express |language=en}}</ref>

== Managing a conflict of interest ==

[[File:Information.svg|25px|alt=Information icon]] Hello, Qfwfq's Qwerty. We [[Help:Getting started|welcome]] your contributions, but if you have an external relationship with the people, places or things [[Special:Contributions/Qfwfq's Qwerty|you have written about]] on the page [[:Low Roar]], you may have a [[conflict of interest]] (COI). Editors with a conflict of interest may be unduly influenced by their connection to the topic. See the '''[[Wikipedia:Conflict of interest|conflict of interest guideline]]''' and '''[[Wikipedia:FAQ/Article subjects|FAQ for article subjects]]''' for more information. We ask that you:

*'''avoid editing or creating''' articles about yourself, your family, friends, colleagues, company, organization, clients, or competitors;
* '''propose changes''' on the [[Help:Talk pages|talk pages]] of affected articles (you can use the [[Wikipedia:Edit Request Wizard|Edit Request Wizard]]), including links or details of [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources|reliable sources]] that support your suggestions;
* '''disclose''' your conflict of interest when discussing affected articles (see {{Section link|Wikipedia:Conflict of interest#How to disclose a COI}});
*'''avoid linking''' to your organization's website in other articles (see {{Section link|Wikipedia:Spam#External link spamming}});
*'''do your best''' to comply with Wikipedia's [[Wikipedia:Core content policies|content policies]].

In addition, you are '''required''' by the [[Wikimedia Foundation]]'s [[foundation:Policy:Terms of Use|terms of use]] to disclose your employer, client, and affiliation with respect to any contribution which forms all or part of work for which you receive, or expect to receive, compensation. See [[Wikipedia:Paid-contribution disclosure]].

Also, editing for the purpose of advertising, publicizing, or promoting anyone or anything is not permitted. Thank you.<!-- THE FOLLOWING CATEGORY SHOULD BE REMOVED IF THE USER IS BLOCKED, OR IT IS DECIDED THAT THIS USER DOES NOT HAVE A COI, OR THIS TEMPLATE HAS BEEN IN PLACE FOR A WHILE WITH NO ACTION. -->{{#ifexpr: ({{#time: U | now}} - 1770505096) < 13150000 | [[Category:User talk pages with conflict of interest notices|{{PAGENAME}}]] | }}<!-- Template:uw-coi --> [[User:Voorts|voorts]] ([[User talk:Voorts|talk]]/[[Special:Contributions/Voorts|contributions]]) 22:58, 7 February 2026 (UTC)

===Zoë movement===
===Zoë movement===
The 20th-century religious revival in Greece included the Zoë movement, founded in 1911. This movement operated independently of the Greek Orthodox Church, with a decentralized structure based primarily in Athens. Its membership included both laypeople and some clergy. Activities of the movement encompassed publications, a nationwide Sunday School program in approximately 7,800 churches, and educational outreach to around 150,000 students. Zoë also sponsored various affiliated organizations, including groups for professionals, youth, parents, and young women nurses. The movement promoted the distribution of Bibles, religious literature, and pamphlets, and encouraged greater lay participation in the Eucharist.<ref>Demetrios J. Constantelos, "The Zoë Movement in Greece," ''St. Vladimir's Seminary Quarterly'' 3, no. 1 (1959): 1–15 [http://intraweb.stockton.edu/eyos/arhu/content/docs/djc%20archive/The%20Zoe%20Movement%20in%20Greece.pdf]</ref>
The 20th-century religious revival in Greece included the Zoë (Zoe) movement, a Greek Orthodox semimonastic association founded in 1907 by Eusebius Matthopoulos. Named after the Greek word for "life", the movement operated largely independently of the institutional Greek Orthodox Church and developed a strong, decentralized organizational structure centered primarily in Athens. Zoë brought together both laypeople and clergy; its core consisted of highly disciplined, unmarried members bound by vows of poverty, chastity, and obedience, approximately half of whom were ordained priests.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Constantelos |first=Demetrios J. |title=The Zoë Movement in Greece |journal=St. Vladimir’s Seminary Quarterly |volume=3 |issue=1 |year=1959 |pages=1–15 |url=http://intraweb.stockton.edu/eyos/arhu/content/docs/djc%20archive/The%20Zoe%20Movement%20in%20Greece.pdf}}</ref><ref name="britannica-greek-orthodox">{{cite web |title=Greek Orthodox Church |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Greek-Orthodox-Church |website=Encyclopaedia Britannica |access-date=2026-02-08}}</ref>


Zoë was actively engaged in teaching, preaching, publishing, and the administration of schools, youth organizations, and professional associations throughout Greece. It sponsored a nationwide Sunday School program operating in approximately 7,800 churches and provided religious education to an estimated 150,000 students. The movement also established affiliated organizations for youth, parents, professionals, and young women nurses, and promoted the widespread distribution of Bibles, religious literature, and pamphlets. Its publications reached hundreds of thousands of copies annually in the period following World War II. Zoë encouraged greater lay participation in liturgical and sacramental life and contributed to a broader revival of religious practice in Greece.<ref>{{cite book |last=Latourette |first=Kenneth Scott |title=Christianity in a Revolutionary Age |volume=4 |year=1961 |pages=523–527 |publisher=Harper & Brothers}}</ref><ref name="britannica-greek-orthodox" />
During the 20th century, seminaries were established, but most graduates pursued careers in teaching rather than parish ministry. In 1920, only 800 of Greece's 4,500 priests had received education beyond the elementary level. By 1959, of approximately 7,000 priests, fewer than five percent had completed both university and seminary training. Monastic life declined but persisted in remote locations such as [[Mount Athos]]. Church life was further disrupted during World War II and the subsequent civil war, with damage to many churches and casualties among clergy and monastics.<ref>Latourette, ''Christianity in a Revolutionary Age'', vol. 4 (1961): 523–527</ref>


The movement was initially viewed with suspicion by the Orthodox episcopate, which objected to its strong independent organization. Its influence was later weakened by internal divisions, including the departure of several members who formed a rival association, Soter, as well as by its close associations with the [[Greek junta|military dictatorship established in Greece]] in 1967. By the late 20th century, Zoë’s prominence had significantly declined.<ref name="britannica-greek-orthodox" />
⚫
In a 2019 interview, [[Christos Yannaras]] stated to [[Norman Russell (theologian)|Norman Russell]] that, although he had participated in the [[Zoë movement]], he had come to regard it as [[Crypto-Protestant]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Metaphysics as a Personal Adventure |url=https://www.churchtimes.co.uk/articles/2019/4-january/books-arts/book-reviews/metaphysics-as-a-personal-adventure-by-norman-russell |access-date=2025-12-24 |website=Church Times}}</ref>

⚫
In a 2019 interview with Norman Russell, the Greek philosopher [[Christos Yannaras]] stated that although he had participated in the Zoë movement in his youth, he later came to regard it as [[crypto-Protestant]] in character.<ref>{{cite web |title=Metaphysics as a Personal Adventure |url=https://www.churchtimes.co.uk/articles/2019/4-january/books-arts/book-reviews/metaphysics-as-a-personal-adventure-by-norman-russell |website=Church Times |access-date=2025-12-24}}</ref>

== Managing a conflict of interest ==

[[File:Information.svg|25px|alt=Information icon]] Hello, Qfwfq's Qwerty. We [[Help:Getting started|welcome]] your contributions, but if you have an external relationship with the people, places or things [[Special:Contributions/Qfwfq's Qwerty|you have written about]] on the page [[:Low Roar]], you may have a [[conflict of interest]] (COI). Editors with a conflict of interest may be unduly influenced by their connection to the topic. See the '''[[Wikipedia:Conflict of interest|conflict of interest guideline]]''' and '''[[Wikipedia:FAQ/Article subjects|FAQ for article subjects]]''' for more information. We ask that you:

*'''avoid editing or creating''' articles about yourself, your family, friends, colleagues, company, organization, clients, or competitors;
* '''propose changes''' on the [[Help:Talk pages|talk pages]] of affected articles (you can use the [[Wikipedia:Edit Request Wizard|Edit Request Wizard]]), including links or details of [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources|reliable sources]] that support your suggestions;
* '''disclose''' your conflict of interest when discussing affected articles (see {{Section link|Wikipedia:Conflict of interest#How to disclose a COI}});
*'''avoid linking''' to your organization's website in other articles (see {{Section link|Wikipedia:Spam#External link spamming}});
*'''do your best''' to comply with Wikipedia's [[Wikipedia:Core content policies|content policies]].

In addition, you are '''required''' by the [[Wikimedia Foundation]]'s [[foundation:Policy:Terms of Use|terms of use]] to disclose your employer, client, and affiliation with respect to any contribution which forms all or part of work for which you receive, or expect to receive, compensation. See [[Wikipedia:Paid-contribution disclosure]].

Also, editing for the purpose of advertising, publicizing, or promoting anyone or anything is not permitted. Thank you.<!-- THE FOLLOWING CATEGORY SHOULD BE REMOVED IF THE USER IS BLOCKED, OR IT IS DECIDED THAT THIS USER DOES NOT HAVE A COI, OR THIS TEMPLATE HAS BEEN IN PLACE FOR A WHILE WITH NO ACTION. -->{{#ifexpr: ({{#time: U | now}} - 1770505096) < 13150000 | [[Category:User talk pages with conflict of interest notices|{{PAGENAME}}]] | }}<!-- Template:uw-coi --> [[User:Voorts|voorts]] ([[User talk:Voorts|talk]]/[[Special:Contributions/Voorts|contributions]]) 22:58, 7 February 2026 (UTC)

'''Washington Heights''' was a [[United States Armed Forces]] housing complex located in [[Shibuya, Tokyo]], during the [[occupation of Japan]] by Allied forces. Constructed in 1946, it remained in operation until 1964, by which point all land had been returned to Japanese control. Today, the site encompasses [[Yoyogi Park]], [[Yoyogi National Gymnasium]], the [[NHK Broadcasting Center]], and other facilities. This installation has a marker for the first powered flight in Japan.

In 1967, Thomas received funds from the Rabinowitz Foundation to write and publish his best-selling autobiography ''[[Down These Mean Streets]]''. The book describes his struggle for survival as a Puerto Rican/Cuban born and raised in the [[barrio]]s of New York. The autobiography explains Thomas's journey of figuring out his identity. It takes readers on a deep dive into his life and how he navigates the struggles he encounters from being [[Afro-Latino]]. The book challenged [[racism]] and racial thinking in the 1940s. Thomas would address the [[racism]] in his family and would claim his black heritage throughout the memoir.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Santiago-Díaz |first1=Eleuterio |last2=Rodríguez |first2=Ilia |title=Writing Race against Literary Whiteness: The Afro-Puerto Rican Outcry of Piri Thomas |journal=Bilingual Review |date=2012 |volume=31 |issue=1 |pages=12–29 |id={{Gale|A504460249}} {{ProQuest|1699279493}} |jstor=24705992 }}</ref> In addition, the book points out key narratives on democracy and racial supremacy.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Blake |first1=Felice |title=What Does It Mean To Be Black?: Gendered Redefinitions of Interethnic Solidarity in Piri Thomas's Down These Mean Streets |journal=African American Review |date=2018 |volume=51 |issue=2 |pages=95–110 |doi=10.1353/afa.2018.0017 |s2cid=165821249 }}</ref> The book, which has been in print for 52 years, was banned in some places but also required reading, depending on the time and place.<ref name="NYT Obit" /> He narrated the rampant racism of the pre-Civil Rights Act of 1964.<ref>{{cite book |last1=González |first1=Christopher |title=Permissible Narratives: The Promise of Latino/a Literature |date=2017 |publisher=Ohio State University Press |isbn=978-0-8142-1350-6 |pages=75–106 }}</ref> His other works include ''Savior, Savior Hold My Hand;'' ''Seven Long Times;'' and ''Stories from El Barrio. with el primo''
In 1967, Thomas received funds from the Rabinowitz Foundation to write and publish his best-selling autobiography ''[[Down These Mean Streets]]''. The book describes his struggle for survival as a Puerto Rican/Cuban born and raised in the [[barrio]]s of New York. The autobiography explains Thomas's journey of figuring out his identity. It takes readers on a deep dive into his life and how he navigates the struggles he encounters from being [[Afro-Latino]]. The book challenged [[racism]] and racial thinking in the 1940s. Thomas would address the [[racism]] in his family and would claim his black heritage throughout the memoir.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Santiago-Díaz |first1=Eleuterio |last2=Rodríguez |first2=Ilia |title=Writing Race against Literary Whiteness: The Afro-Puerto Rican Outcry of Piri Thomas |journal=Bilingual Review |date=2012 |volume=31 |issue=1 |pages=12–29 |id={{Gale|A504460249}} {{ProQuest|1699279493}} |jstor=24705992 }}</ref> In addition, the book points out key narratives on democracy and racial supremacy.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Blake |first1=Felice |title=What Does It Mean To Be Black?: Gendered Redefinitions of Interethnic Solidarity in Piri Thomas's Down These Mean Streets |journal=African American Review |date=2018 |volume=51 |issue=2 |pages=95–110 |doi=10.1353/afa.2018.0017 |s2cid=165821249 }}</ref> The book, which has been in print for 52 years, was banned in some places but also required reading, depending on the time and place.<ref name="NYT Obit" /> He narrated the rampant racism of the pre-Civil Rights Act of 1964.<ref>{{cite book |last1=González |first1=Christopher |title=Permissible Narratives: The Promise of Latino/a Literature |date=2017 |publisher=Ohio State University Press |isbn=978-0-8142-1350-6 |pages=75–106 }}</ref> His other works include ''Savior, Savior Hold My Hand;'' ''Seven Long Times;'' and ''Stories from El Barrio. with el primo''


One of his most known works is the chapter in ''Down These Mean Streets'' called ''Brothers Under the Skin.'' In this chapter, Piri Thomas brings light to an altercation between him and his brother in which they argued about their race. Piri's brother, Jose, is adamant about being only Puerto Rican and white. While Piri is able to acknowledge that he has black ancestry and is willing to go "down south" to learn more about his culture. The brothers go back and forth on the topic about their race and end up physically hurting one another. Both their parents seem to deny the fact that they have Black heritage as well and Piri's mother believes that he does not like to be "un negrito".<ref>{{Cite book |last=Thomas |first=Piri |title=Brothers Under The Skin |date=April 12, 1967 |publisher=Alfred A. Knopf }}</ref>

Constructed in 1946, it remained in operation until 1964, by which point all land had been returned to Japanese control. Today, the site encompasses [[Yoyogi Park]], [[Yoyogi National Gymnasium]], the [[NHK Broadcasting Center]], and other facilities. This installation has a marker for the first powered flight in Japan.

Link suggestions feature: 2 links added.

← Previous revision Revision as of 22:58, 7 February 2026
Line 15: Line 15:
As an academic discipline, soundscape ecology shares some characteristics with other fields of inquiry but is also distinct from them in significant ways.<ref name=Pijanowski_etal_2011a/> For instance, [[acoustic ecology]] is also concerned with the study of multiple sound sources. However, acoustic ecology, which derives from the founding work of [[R. Murray Schafer]] and [[Barry Truax]], primarily focuses on human perception of soundscapes. Soundscape ecology seeks a broader perspective by considering soundscape effects on communities of living organisms, human and other, and the potential interactions between sounds in the environment.<ref name="Krause, Bernie 2012"/> Compared to soundscape ecology, the discipline of [[bioacoustics]] tends to have a narrower interest in individual species' [[physiology|physiological]] and behavioral mechanisms of auditory communication. Soundscape ecology also borrows heavily from some concepts in [[landscape ecology]], which focuses on ecological patterns and processes occurring over multiple spatial scales.<ref name=Pijanowski_etal_2011a/><ref name=Pijanowski_etal_2011b/> Landscapes may directly influence soundscapes as some organisms use physical features of their habitat to alter their vocalizations. For example, [[baboon]]s and other animals exploit specific habitats to generate [[echo (phenomenon)|echoes]] of the sounds they produce.<ref name=Pijanowski_etal_2011a/><ref name="Krause, Bernie 2012"/>
As an academic discipline, soundscape ecology shares some characteristics with other fields of inquiry but is also distinct from them in significant ways.<ref name=Pijanowski_etal_2011a/> For instance, [[acoustic ecology]] is also concerned with the study of multiple sound sources. However, acoustic ecology, which derives from the founding work of [[R. Murray Schafer]] and [[Barry Truax]], primarily focuses on human perception of soundscapes. Soundscape ecology seeks a broader perspective by considering soundscape effects on communities of living organisms, human and other, and the potential interactions between sounds in the environment.<ref name="Krause, Bernie 2012"/> Compared to soundscape ecology, the discipline of [[bioacoustics]] tends to have a narrower interest in individual species' [[physiology|physiological]] and behavioral mechanisms of auditory communication. Soundscape ecology also borrows heavily from some concepts in [[landscape ecology]], which focuses on ecological patterns and processes occurring over multiple spatial scales.<ref name=Pijanowski_etal_2011a/><ref name=Pijanowski_etal_2011b/> Landscapes may directly influence soundscapes as some organisms use physical features of their habitat to alter their vocalizations. For example, [[baboon]]s and other animals exploit specific habitats to generate [[echo (phenomenon)|echoes]] of the sounds they produce.<ref name=Pijanowski_etal_2011a/><ref name="Krause, Bernie 2012"/>


The function and importance of sound in the environment may not be fully appreciated unless one adopts an organismal perspective on sound perception, and, in this way, soundscape ecology is also informed by [[sensory ecology]].<ref name=Pijanowski_etal_2011a/><ref name=Pijanowski_etal_2011b/> Sensory ecology focuses on understanding the [[sensory system]]s of organisms and the biological function of information obtained from these systems. In many cases, humans must acknowledge that sensory modalities and information used by other organisms may not be obvious from an anthropocentric viewpoint. This perspective has already highlighted many instances where organisms rely heavily on sound cues generated within their natural environments to perform important biological functions. For example, a broad range of [[crustacean]]s are known to respond to biophony generated around [[coral reef]]s. Species that must settle on reefs to complete their developmental cycle are attracted to reef noise while [[pelagic]] and [[nocturnal]] crustaceans are repelled by the same acoustic signal, presumably as a mechanism to avoid [[predation]] (predator densities are high in reef habitats).<ref name=Simpson_etal_2011>{{Cite journal | last1 = Simpson | first1 = S. D. | last2 = Radford | first2 = A. N. | last3 = Tickle | first3 = E. J. | last4 = Meekan | first4 = M. G. | last5 = Jeffs | first5 = A. G. | editor1-last = Klimley | editor1-first = A. Peter | title = Adaptive Avoidance of Reef Noise | doi = 10.1371/journal.pone.0016625 | journal = PLOS ONE | volume = 6 | issue = 2 | article-number = e16625 | year = 2011 | pmid = 21326604| pmc =3033890 | bibcode = 2011PLoSO...616625S | doi-access = free }}</ref> Similarly, juvenile fish may use biophony as a navigational cue to locate their natal reefs,<ref name=Simpson_etal_2005>{{Cite journal | last1 = Simpson | first1 = S. D. | last2 = Meekan | first2 = M. | last3 = Montgomery | first3 = J. | last4 = McCauley | first4 = R. | last5 = Jeffs | first5 = A. | title = Homeward Sound | doi = 10.1126/science.1107406 | journal = Science | volume = 308 | issue = 5719 | page = 221 | year = 2005 | pmid = 15821083| s2cid = 1064954 }}</ref> and may also be encouraged to resettle damaged coral reefs by playback of healthy reef sound.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Gordon|first1=Timothy A. C.|last2=Radford|first2=Andrew N.|last3=Davidson|first3=Isla K.|last4=Barnes|first4=Kasey|last5=McCloskey|first5=Kieran|last6=Nedelec|first6=Sophie L.|last7=Meekan|first7=Mark G.|last8=McCormick|first8=Mark I.|last9=Simpson|first9=Stephen D.|date=2019-11-29|title=Acoustic enrichment can enhance fish community development on degraded coral reef habitat|journal=Nature Communications|language=en|volume=10|issue=1|page=5414|doi=10.1038/s41467-019-13186-2|pmid=31784508|pmc=6884498|bibcode=2019NatCo..10.5414G|issn=2041-1723|doi-access=free}}</ref> Other species' movement patterns are influenced by geophony, as in the case of the [[Hyperolius nitidulus|reed frog]] which is known to disperse away from the sound of fire.<ref name=Grafe_etal_2002>{{Cite journal | last1 = Grafe | first1 = T. U. | last2 = Dobler | first2 = S. | last3 = Linsenmair | first3 = K. E. | doi = 10.1098/rspb.2002.1974 | title = Frogs flee from the sound of fire | journal = Proceedings of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences | volume = 269 | issue = 1495 | pages = 999–1003 | year = 2002 | pmid = 12028755| pmc = 1690992 | bibcode = 2002PBioS.269..999G }}</ref> In addition, a variety of bird and mammal species use auditory cues, such as movement noise, in order to locate prey.<ref name=Barber_etal_2010>{{Cite journal | last1 = Barber | first1 = J. R. | last2 = Crooks | first2 = K. R. | last3 = Fristrup | first3 = K. M. | doi = 10.1016/j.tree.2009.08.002 | title = The costs of chronic noise exposure for terrestrial organisms | journal = Trends in Ecology & Evolution | volume = 25 | issue = 3 | pages = 180–9 | year = 2010 | pmid = 19762112 | bibcode = 2010TEcoE..25..180B }}</ref> Disturbances created by periods of environmental noise may also be exploited by some animals while foraging. For example, insects that prey on spiders concentrate [[foraging]] activities during episodes of environmental noise to avoid detection by their prey.<ref name=Wignall_etal_2011>{{Cite journal | last1 = Wignall | first1 = A. E. | last2 = Jackson | first2 = R. R. | last3 = Wilcox | first3 = R. S. | last4 = Taylor | first4 = P. ==Terminology==
==Terminology==
Line 77: Line 77:
==Soundscape conservation==
==Soundscape conservation==


The discipline of [[conservation biology]] has traditionally been concerned with the preservation of [[biodiversity]] and the habitats that organisms are dependent upon. However, soundscape ecology encourages biologists to consider natural soundscapes as resources worthy of conservation efforts. Soundscapes that come from relatively untrammeled habitats have value for wildlife as demonstrated by the numerous negative effects of anthropogenic noise on various species.<ref name=Barber_etal_2010/> Organisms that use acoustic cues generated by their prey may be particularly impacted by human-altered soundscapes.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Krause | first1 = Bernie | last2 = Farina | first2 = Almo | year = 2016 | title = Using ecoacoustic methods to survey the impacts of climate change on biodiversity | journal = Biological Conservation | volume = 195 | pages = 245–254 | doi=10.1016/j.biocon.2016.01.013 | bibcode = 2016BCons.195..245K }}</ref> In this situation, the (unintentional) senders of the acoustic signals will have no incentive to compensate for masking imposed by anthropogenic sound. In addition, natural soundscapes can have benefits for human wellbeing and may help generate a distinct sense of place, connecting people to the environment and providing unique aesthetic experiences.<ref name=Dumyahn_and_Pijanowski_2011/> Because of the various values inherent in natural soundscapes, they may be considered [[ecosystem services]] that are provisioned by intact, functioning [[ecosystems]].<ref name=Pijanowski_etal_2011a/> Targets for soundscape conservation may include soundscapes necessary for the persistence of threatened wildlife, soundscapes that are themselves being severely altered by anthrophony, and soundscapes that represent unique places or cultural values.<ref name=Dumyahn_and_Pijanowski_2011/> Some governments and management agencies have begun to consider preservation of natural soundscapes as an environmental priority.<ref>Bernie Krause. (2002) "Wild Soundscapes in the National Parks: An Educational Program Guide to Listening and Recording, pub. National Park Service. 1–86.</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Krause | first1 = Bernie | last2 = Gage | first2 = Stuart H. | last3 = Joo | first3 = Wooyeong | year = 2011 | title = Measuring and interpreting the temporal variability in the soundscape at four places in Sequoia National Park | journal = Landscape Ecol. | volume = 26| issue = 9| pages = 1247–1256| doi = 10.1007/s10980-011-9639-6 | bibcode = 2011LaEco..26.1247K | s2cid = 2490762 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Dumyahn | first1 = S. L. | last2 = Pijanowski | first2 = B. C. | year = 2011 | title = Soundscape conservation | journal = Landscape Ecology | volume = 26 | issue = 9| page = 1327 | doi = 10.1007/s10980-011-9635-x | bibcode = 2011LaEco..26.1327D | s2cid = 5820389 }}</ref> In the United States, the National Park Service's [[Natural Sounds and Night Skies Division]] is working to protect natural and cultural soundscapes.

The '''Anioma people''' (''[[Help:IPA/English|/æˈniːɒmɑː/]] [[Help:Pronunciation respelling key|ah-NEE-o-ma]], [[American English|US]]: [[Help:IPA/English|/əˈniːɒmɑː/]] [[Help:Pronunciation respelling key|uh-NEE-o-mah]];'' ''Ndí Ániọ̀mà'' {{Audio|LL-Q33578 (ibo)-Vivian Amalachukwu-Ndí Ániọ̀mà.wav|Listen|help=no}}) of present day [[Delta State]], Nigeria encompass and are native to the nine northeastern [[Local government areas of Nigeria|Local Government Areas]] of Delta State and the Ika communities of Edo State. Politically, the Anioma occupy the [[Delta North Senatorial District]] where they are the majority group.
The '''Anioma people''' (''[[Help:IPA/English|/æˈniːɒmɑː/]] [[Help:Pronunciation respelling key|ah-NEE-o-ma]], [[American English|US]]: [[Help:IPA/English|/əˈniːɒmɑː/]] [[Help:Pronunciation respelling key|uh-NEE-o-mah]];'' ''Ndí Ániọ̀mà'' {{Audio|LL-Q33578 (ibo)-Vivian Amalachukwu-Ndí Ániọ̀mà.wav|Listen|help=no}}) of present day [[Delta State]], Nigeria encompass and are native to the nine northeastern [[Local government areas of Nigeria|Local Government Areas]] of Delta State and the Ika communities of Edo State. Politically, the Anioma occupy the [[Delta North Senatorial District]] where they are the majority group.


Today, the population of the Anioma is estimated today to be at approximately 3.1 million.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Federal Republic of Nigeria, Official gazette |issue=24 |year=2007 |volume= 94}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=About|url=https://www.aniomavoice.org/about/|access-date=2021-09-18|website=ANIOMA VOICE WORLDWIDE FOUNDATION|language=en-US|archive-date=2021-04-27|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210427210444/https://www.aniomavoice.org/about/|url-status=dead}}</ref> The largest Anioma settlement and [[urban area]] is the [[Asaba|Delta State Capital Territory]], which incorporates the [[Asaba|city of Asaba]] along the [[Niger River]], with Okpanam, [[Igbuzo]]r and surrounding communities.<ref>{{Cite web |title=NED NWOKO'S STATE CREATION BILL – THISDAYLIVE |url=https://www.thisdaylive.com/index.php/2024/07/26/ned-nwokos-state-creation-bill/ |access-date=2024-07-26 |website=www.thisdaylive.com}}</ref> The Anioma natively speak western dialects of the [[Igbo language]], a [[Niger–Congo languages|Niger-Congo language]], as well as several minority languages related to the cultures they lie contingent to.
Today, the population of the Anioma is estimated today to be at approximately 1.8 million.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Federal Republic of Nigeria, Official gazette |issue=24 |year=2007 |volume= 94}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=About|url=https://www.aniomavoice.org/about/|access-date=2021-09-18|website=ANIOMA VOICE WORLDWIDE FOUNDATION|language=en-US|archive-date=2021-04-27|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210427210444/https://www.aniomavoice.org/about/|url-status=dead}}</ref> The largest Anioma settlement and [[urban area]] is the [[Asaba|Delta State Capital Territory]], which incorporates the [[Asaba|city of Asaba]] along the [[Niger River]], with Okpanam, [[Igbuzo]]r and surrounding communities.<ref>{{Cite web |title=NED NWOKO'S STATE CREATION BILL – THISDAYLIVE |url=https://www.thisdaylive.com/index.php/2024/07/26/ned-nwokos-state-creation-bill/ |access-date=2024-07-26 |website=www.thisdaylive.com}}</ref> The Anioma natively speak western dialects of the [[Igbo language]], a [[Niger–Congo languages|Niger-Congo language]], as well as several minority languages related to the cultures they lie contingent to.

Phase 2 was constructed from 2016 to 2017.<ref name=nairobileo-kenyanbehind /> It included {{convert|70|km}} of roads and [[solar powered]] street lights.<ref name=nairobileo-kenyanbehind /><ref name=constructionreview-transformkenya /> It also included the Hamptons hospital.<ref name=nairobileo-kenyanbehind /><ref name=constructionreview-transformkenya /> Some sources say this hospital has 5000 beds.<ref name=nairobileo-kenyanbehind /> This would have made it the [[List of largest hospital campuses| second largest hospital in the world]].<ref name=mediapart-unfinished /> Others say only the first section of the hospital including the cancer treatment centre were part of phase 2 with other departments to be added in phase 3.<ref name=constructionreview-transformkenya /> As part of a 2022 [[Mediapart]] investigation, journalists contacted the hospital and were told the Advanced Cancer Treatment and Diagnostic Centre was not operational and that the facility saw under a hundred people a day, primarily for [[malaria]] treatment.<ref name=mediapart-unfinished>{{Cite web |title=Unfinished projects and claims for unpaid bills: behind the ‘success story’ of Julius Mwale |url=https://www.mediapart.fr/en/journal/international/191123/unfinished-projects-and-claims-unpaid-bills-behind-success-story-julius-mwale |last=Bonnerot |first=Clément |date=2023-11-19 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20260125205110/https://www.mediapart.fr/en/journal/international/191123/unfinished-projects-and-claims-unpaid-bills-behind-success-story-julius-mwale |archive-date=2026-01-25 |access-date=2026-01-25 |website=[[Mediapart]] |last2=Rolley |first2=Sonia}}</ref>

County Government to halt construction works over approval issues.<ref name="Controversy"/> In August 2018, the Kakamega County Government, led by then Governor Wycliffe Oparanya, publicly agreed with Despite the local support and apparent victories against adversarial politicians, MMTC and affiliates have not been without controversy. Founder Julius Mwale and associated entities faced multiple legal challenges over contractual obligations and other business disputes. Several cases brought against Mwale have been deemed by the court to be without merit and dismissed, and in others, the plaintiffs in question were ordered to complete their contractual obligations prior to demanding payment. Remaining disputes appear to be ongoing, with Mwale's team appealing a few [[High Court (Kenya)|High Court of Kenya]] judgments against them. '''''Man vs. Baby''''' is a 2025 British [[Television comedy|comedy]] television [[miniseries]] created and written by [[Rowan Atkinson]] and [[William Davies (screenwriter)|William Davies]]. A follow-up to ''[[Man vs. Bee]]'' (2022), Atkinson reprises his role as Trevor Bingley.
'''''Man vs. Baby''''' is a 2025 British [[Television comedy|comedy]] television [[miniseries]] created and written by [[Rowan Atkinson]] and [[William Davies (screenwriter)|William Davies]]. A follow-up to ''[[Man vs. Bee]]'' (2022), Atkinson reprises his role as Trevor Bingley.


''Man vs. Baby'' premiered on 11 December 2025 on [[Netflix]] and received positive reviews from critics.
[[Man vs. Baby|''Man vs. Baby'']] premiered on 11 December 2025 on [[Netflix]] and received positive reviews from critics.

[[Man vs. Baby|''Man vs. Baby'']] consists of 4 episodes that are roughly 30 minutes each


== Premise ==
== Premise ==
After the chaos of ''[[Man vs. Bee]]'', Trevor Bingley has taken a quieter job as a school caretaker. A lucrative Christmas penthouse gig lures him back — and when no one collects the Baby Jesus from the school nativity, Trevor finds himself with an unexpected companion over the holidays.<ref name="NMC">{{cite web |title=Man Vs Baby |website=Netflix Media Center |url=https://media.netflix.com/only-on-netflix/81923753 |access-date=8 November 2025}}</ref>

Line 6: Line 6:
==Doubly articulated consonants==
==Doubly articulated consonants==
{{Main article|Doubly articulated consonant}}
{{Main article|Doubly articulated consonant}}
An example of a doubly articulated consonant is the [[voiceless labial-velar stop]] {{IPA|[k͡p]}}, which is pronounced simultaneously at the [[Soft palate|velum]] (a [k]) and at the lips (a [p]).
An example of a doubly articulated consonant is the [[voiceless labial–velar stop]] {{IPA|[k͡p]}}, which is pronounced simultaneously at the [[Soft palate|velum]] (a {{IPAblink|k}}) and at the lips (a {{IPAblink|p}}).


In practically all languages of the world that have doubly articulated consonants, these are either [[click consonant|clicks]] or [[labial-velar consonant|labial-velars]].
In practically all languages of the world that have doubly articulated consonants, these are either [[click consonant|clicks]] or [[labial–velar]]s.


==Consonants with secondary articulation==
==Consonants with secondary articulation==
{{Main article|Secondary articulation}}
{{Main article|Secondary articulation}}
An example of a consonant with secondary articulation is the voiceless [[labialization|labialized]] velar stop {{IPA|[kʷ]}} has only a single stop articulation, [[velar consonant|velar]] [k], with a simultaneous [[approximant consonant|approximant-like]] rounding of the lips.
An example of a consonant with secondary articulation is the voiceless [[labialization|labialized]] velar stop {{IPA|[kʷ]}} has only a single stop articulation, [[velar consonant|velar]] {{IPA|[k]}}, with a simultaneous [[approximant]]-like rounding of the lips.


There is a large number of common secondary articulations. The most frequently encountered are [[labialization]] (such as {{IPA|[kʷ]}}), [[Palatalization (phonetics)|palatalization]] (such as the [[Slavic languages|Slavic]] "soft" consonants like {{IPA|[pʲ]}}), [[velarization]] (such as the [[English language|English]] [[Velarized alveolar lateral approximant|"dark" el]] {{IPA|[lˠ]}}), and [[pharyngealization]] (such as the [[Arabic language|Arabic]] [[emphatic consonants]] like {{IPA|[tˤ]}}).
There is a large number of common secondary articulations. The most frequently encountered are [[labialization]] (such as {{IPA|[kʷ]}}), [[Palatalization (phonetics)|palatalization]] (such as [[Russian phonology#Palatalization|"soft" consonants]] like {{IPA|[pʲ]}} in [[Russian language|Russian]]), [[velarization]] (such as [[Velarized alveolar lateral approximant|"dark" ''l'']] {{IPA|[lˠ]}} in [[English language|English]]), and [[pharyngealization]] (such as [[emphatic consonants]] like {{IPA|[tˤ]}} in [[Arabic language|Arabic]]).


==Distinction between the two classes==
==Distinction between the two classes==
As might be expected from the approximant-like nature of secondary articulation, it is not always easy to tell whether a co-articulated [[approximant consonant]] such as {{IPA|/w/}} is doubly or secondarily articulated. In some English dialects,{{which?|date=September 2023}} for example, {{IPA|/w/}} is a [[Voiced labio-velar approximant|labialized velar]] that could be transcribed as {{IPA|[ɰʷ]}}.
As might be expected from the approximant-like nature of secondary articulation, it is not always easy to tell whether a co-articulated approximant such as {{IPAslink|w}} is doubly or secondarily articulated. In some English dialects,{{which?|date=September 2023}} for example, {{IPA|/w/}} is a [[labialized velar]] that could be transcribed as {{IPA|[ɰʷ]}}.


==Similar phones==
==Similar phones==
The [[Glottal consonant|glottis]] controls [[phonation]], and works simultaneously with many consonants. It is not normally considered an articulator, and an [[ejective consonant|ejective]] such as {{IPA|[kʼ]}}, with simultaneous closure of the velum and glottis, is not normally considered to be a co-articulated consonant.
The [[Glottal consonant|glottis]] controls [[phonation]], and works simultaneously with many consonants. It is not normally considered an articulator, and an [[ejective consonant|ejective]] such as {{IPAblink|kʼ}}, with simultaneous closure of the velum and glottis, is not normally considered to be a co-articulated consonant.
